metadata.title: An Initial Functional and Security Coverage Analysis of AWS Security Agent Against the OWASP Top 10 (2025)
metadata.author: Ivan Bylina

abstract: This study presents an initial functional and security coverage analysis of AWS Security Agent, a newly introduced AWS-managed, GenAI-enabled security assessment service designed to support design review, code analysis, and penetration testing within the software development lifecycle. The evaluation is based on empirical testing of the service, supplemented by a systematic review of publicly available AWS documentation. The study examines three core capabilities: design security review, code security review and on-demand penetration testing, evaluates their implementation characteristics, operational limitations, and coverage of the OWASP Top 10 (2025) application security risks. Results indicate support for context-aware, multi-step penetration testing and real-time pull-request analysis, with effective detection of injection vulnerabilities. OWASP Top 10 coverage analysis reveals significant variation across risk categories, with strongest coverage in injection vulnerabilities and access control, moderate coverage in security misconfiguration and insecure design, and weakest coverage in software supply chain security, cryptographic validation beyond TLS checks, and security logging. This work provides an objective, practitioner-focused assessment of current capabilities and limitations and does not constitute a security certification or endorsement of the service.

sections.title: Introduction
paragraphs: Application security teams must secure applications as they evolve through design, coding and deployment. Traditional security reviews and penetration tests are typically manual and scheduled infrequently, leading to gaps and late findings. AWS introduced the "Security Agent" as a AI agent designed to embed security into each stage of the software development lifecycle [1]. The service was first publicly announced at AWS re:Invent 2025, held December 1-5, 2025, signaling AWS’s intent to operationalize generative AI-assisted security reviews within mainstream development workflows [2]. The agent provides design reviews, code security reviews and multi-step penetration testing within a centralized web interface, aiming to make expert-level security assessments available on demand and at scale [1]. The official documentation confirms that AWS Security Agent operates across AWS, on-premise, hybrid, multicloud, and SaaS environments [1] and consolidates findings from design, code and penetration tests in one place.

subsections.title: Design Security Review
paragraphs: The design review capability allows security teams to upload design documents (architectural diagrams, system designs, data-flow diagrams and threat models) and assess them against organizational security requirements. The official AWS documentation confirms that AWS Security Agent shifts security left by providing real-time security feedback on design documents and assessing compliance with organizational security requirements before any code is written [1]. Security teams upload documents through the web application and receive remediation guidance to prioritize findings [1]. The agent supports custom security requirements-teams can define description, applicability, compliance criteria and remediation guidance for each requirement. During testing, it was noted that custom requirements are defined through free-text fields limited to 500 characters for descriptions and 10 000 characters for other fields, and the underlying model interprets them, which may change over time. The design review runs entirely in the external web application opened from the AWS console. Supported formats include markdown, PDF and common architectural diagram formats, but uploading is done manually; there is currently no CLI or API to automate submissions.

subsections.title: Code Security Review
paragraphs: Code review analyzes pull requests in source control repositories against security requirements and the OWASP Top 10. The official AWS documentation states that AWS Security Agent proactively secures applications by analyzing pull requests against organizational security requirements and common vulnerabilities like missing input validation and SQL injection risks [1]. Developers receive remediation guidance directly in their GitHub workflow [1]. The official AWS documentation for reviewing code security findings in GitHub confirms that code review is triggered when a pull request is marked as "Ready for review" in repositories where code review capability is enabled, and that draft pull requests are not analyzed [3]. The AWS News Feed article notes that the agent's code review checks GitHub pull requests for OWASP Top Ten vulnerabilities and policy violations [4]. The official AWS documentation only mentions GitHub integration [3]. During testing, it was observed that the public preview integrates only with GitHub via a GitHub App, supports up to 20 private repositories per integration [5] and does not scan public repositories. Pull requests are the only unit of analysis - full repository scans are not supported. Remediation guidance and suggested fixes are posted directly in the developer's workflow, but customizing the checks beyond the defined security requirements is limited.

subsections.title: On-Demand Penetration Testing
paragraphs: AWS Security Agent's penetration testing capability performs multi-step attack simulations on web applications. The official AWS documentation confirms that AWS Security Agent delivers on-demand penetration testing by deploying specialized AI agents to discover, validate, report and remediate security vulnerabilities through tailored multi-step attack scenarios [1]. The agent understands the application's context by analyzing source code and documentation to identify and exploit vulnerabilities that automated security scanning tools cannot find [1]. It documents findings with impact analysis, reproducible attack paths, and creates pull requests with ready-to-implement code fixes [1]. The official AWS documentation for creating penetration tests specifies that only verified domains can be included in penetration tests and that VPC configuration is only required for testing private applications hosted within an Amazon Virtual Private Cloud [6]. It is promoted as automating context-aware penetration tests that scale across many applications [4]. The National CIO Review notes that the agent continuously scans workloads for vulnerabilities and performs penetration testing tailored to the application's structure and intended behavior, eliminating the need to wait for human‑led assessments [7]. The ComputerWeekly report adds that the agent understands the design, code and security requirements of a workload and can create a customised attack plan to expose vulnerabilities before an application reaches production [8]. During testing, it was noted that all penetration tests require a verified domain (with DNS TXT record) [6], and for private applications hosted within a VPC, additional VPC configuration is also required [6]. Tests can include contextual artifacts such as API documentation, threat models, source code archives and GitHub repositories. Only HTTP/HTTPS targets are supported; custom ports and other protocols are not. The agent creates multiple action groups (information disclosure, business logic vulnerabilities, unrestricted resource consumption, authentication bypass, etc.), uses static analysis tasks to inspect the source, and then launches validators that exploit vulnerabilities to minimise false positives. The risk categories available for testing include arbitrary file upload, code injection, command injection, cross‑site scripting (XSS), insecure direct object references, JSON Web Token vulnerabilities, local file inclusion, path traversal, privilege escalation, server‑side request forgery (SSRF), server‑side template injection, SQL injection and XML external entity attacks.

subsections.title: Setup and Permissions
paragraphs: AWS Security Agent was tested using a read-only IAM user with permissions gradually added. The web console provided clear error messages for many missing permissions, but some errors required examining logs to identify the missing IAM policies. The agent can only be enabled via the AWS console; there is no CLI, CloudFormation template or SDK interface for configuration-making it a click-ops process. All interactions occur via a web console with no CLI or official AWS CLI commands available. The preview is available only in the us-east-1 region and requires creation of an "Agent Space". Connecting GitHub triggers installation of a GitHub App with repository access restricted to selected or all repositories.

subsections.title: Design Review Findings
paragraphs: The design review accepts supported file types via manual upload. In some highly regulated environments, uploading documents through a web UI may be blocked, limiting adoption. The service was tested with basic design documents, and it was observed that policies such as "Secure by Default, Tenant Isolation, Secret Protection, Trusted Cryptography, Audit Logging, Authorization, Log Protection, Information Protection, Privileged Access and Authentication" were applied. When the design intentionally violated requirements, the agent failed corresponding policies; when the design mentioned the required topics, half of the policies were marked as needing more details. Uploading irrelevant documents led to all policies being marked not applicable. Custom security requirements worked as expected; a test rule designed to block specific fictional terms was triggered when related keywords appeared in variable names. However, the manual upload process and lack of automation make it difficult to integrate design review into CI/CD pipelines. During testing, it was noted that the underlying language model performing analysis is not documented; thus the behaviour may change as models are updated. This lack of determinism makes it difficult to rely on the tool for strict policy enforcement.

subsections.title: Code Review Findings
paragraphs: Code review worked only for private GitHub repositories configured through the GitHub App. Pull requests were evaluated against the same security requirements used for design review and against common vulnerability patterns. The agent does not analyze entire codebases-only changes in pull requests. Custom security requirements could be reused across design and code reviews. There is no support for public repositories, and integration with other source control systems (Bitbucket, GitLab, CodeCommit) was not present in the preview. The tool offers two modes: one to check custom security requirements and another to detect "security vulnerability findings" that resemble the output of Amazon CodeGuru Reviewer; the latter uses rules similar to open-source tools like Bandit and Infer.

subsections.title: Penetration Testing Findings
paragraphs: To start a penetration test, users must verify ownership of a target domain by creating a DNS TXT record. Automatic verification via Route53 often fails, requiring manual DNS record creation. The penetration testing workflow opens in an external web application separate from the main AWS console. Tests can target an external domain or run from within a VPC; however, the tool does not support VPCs using the 10.0.0.0/16 CIDR because it conflicts with the agent's addressing. Custom ports and non-HTTP protocols are unsupported; specifying a port in the URL causes the run to start but never succeeds. When a VPC is selected, outbound internet connectivity is required even to fetch GitHub context. Penetration tests also request CloudWatch log groups as destinations, but pre-created log groups sometimes fail validation due to undocumented naming conventions; leaving the field blank allows the agent to create log groups automatically. Contextual resources can include S3 buckets (only plaintext API documentation, threat models or zipped source code archives), GitHub repositories and plain‑text credentials via the UI. Lambda functions and Secrets Manager entries are used solely to provide authentication credentials. During scanning, the agent builds a sitemap, performs static analysis of frameworks, business logic, important flows and misconfigurations, and then launches validator tasks for risk categories such as arbitrary file upload, code and command injection, XSS, IDOR, JWT vulnerabilities, local file inclusion, path traversal, privilege escalation, SSRF, SSTI, SQL injection and XML external entity attacks. The agent uses tools like testssl.sh to check TLS configurations. It produces detailed findings with CVSS scores, exploit steps and remediation guidance. However, exploitation of complex vulnerabilities that require running external tooling or interacting with local services (labelled "Hard" during testing) is not supported. Custom exploitation code added to the context caused hallucinations - e.g., the agent incorrectly marked a vulnerability as CVE-2021-21311 based on proof for CVE-2018-7667. Additionally, the service prohibits creation of custom infrastructure or use of localhost services, limiting validation of sophisticated scenarios.

sections.title: Limitations and Gaps
paragraphs: The following tables summarise limitations identified during testing and map them to available documentation where possible. Table 1 lists limitations mentioned in official AWS sources (blogs and documentation) and confirmed through testing. Table 2 lists limitations observed during testing that are not mentioned in the sources reviewed.

tables.caption: Table 1 - Documented limitations
rows: Service is in preview and available only in US East (N. Virginia). AWS News Feed notes that AWS Security Agent is free during the preview and available only in the US East (N. Virginia) region [4].

Access is through a web-based interface with no CLI, API, or scheduling capabilities. Official AWS documentation states that the agent provides design reviews, code security reviews and multi-step penetration testing within a centralized web interface [1]. Official AWS documentation on security considerations explicitly states that "AWS Security Agent does not have public APIs or the ability to schedule the pen test runs" [9]. Configuration, design uploads, repository integration and test execution can only be performed via the console and external web app; there is no AWS CLI or SDK support. Tests must be triggered manually via the console; cannot integrate penetration tests into CI/CD pipelines or scheduled assessments.

Code review analyzes GitHub pull requests rather than full repositories. AWS News Feed states that code review checks GitHub pull requests for OWASP Top Ten vulnerabilities and policy violations [4]. The preview only reviews pull requests on private repositories; it does not scan entire codebases.

Only GitHub integration available for code review. Official AWS documentation for reviewing code security findings in GitHub states that code review is triggered when a pull request is marked as "Ready for review" in repositories where code review capability is enabled, and only GitHub is mentioned throughout the documentation [3]. The documentation does not mention support for other source control systems. The preview only supports GitHub integration; other SCM systems (GitLab, Bitbucket, CodeCommit) are not available.

Limit of 20 integrated resources per integration. Official AWS documentation on Service Quotas specifies that integrated resources per integration are limited to 20 per integration, and this quota is not adjustable [5]. Large organizations may have more repositories than allowed and must manage multiple integrations or agent spaces.

Limit of 20 integrations per account per region. Official AWS documentation on Service Quotas specifies that integrations are limited to 20 per account per region, and this quota is not adjustable [5]. Organizations with many repositories may need to create multiple agent spaces or request quota increases.

Limit of 20 custom security requirements per account per region. Official AWS documentation on Service Quotas specifies that custom security requirements are limited to 20 per account per region, and this quota is not adjustable [5]. Organizations with extensive security policies may need to prioritize which requirements to configure.

Concurrent pentest runs limited to 5 per account per region. Official AWS documentation on Service Quotas specifies that concurrent pentest runs are limited to 5 per account per region, though this quota is adjustable [5]. Multiple penetration tests can run simultaneously, but the limit may require scheduling for organizations with high testing needs.

Public repositories unsupported. Official AWS documentation on security best practices explicitly states that "AWS Security Agent does not provide code security guidance for public repositories. It will not comment on public repositories or open-source projects where security findings would be publicly visible" [10]. Only private repositories can be scanned, preventing open-source projects from using the service.

VPC CIDR range 10.0.0.0/16 not supported. Official AWS documentation on connecting agent to private VPC resources explicitly states that "For VPC penetration tests, VPC CIDR ranges that overlap with the 10.0.0.0/16 range are currently not supported" [11]. Common corporate VPC ranges conflict with the agent; penetration tests using VPCs with this CIDR range will fail.

VPC must have outbound internet connectivity. Official AWS documentation on infrastructure security states that "AWS Security Agent requires internet access to perform penetration testing on target applications and for control plane operations" [12]. Penetration tests inside a VPC fail if there is no outbound connectivity.

tables.caption: Table 2 - Limitations observed in the preview not documented in sources
rows: Design review and code review rely on manual uploads and cannot fetch from VPC or internal file shares. Organizations with strict egress controls or blocked uploads cannot use the feature; files must be manually uploaded to an external web app.

Only HTTP/HTTPS targets supported; custom ports unsupported. Applications listening on non-standard ports or protocols cannot be tested; specifying a port in the URL causes the test to hang or fail without clear error messages.

Risk of hallucinated vulnerabilities when additional exploit code is provided. The agent may misattribute vulnerabilities (e.g., marking CVE-2021-21311 validated using proof for CVE-2018-7667), reducing confidence in findings.

Complex exploitation scenarios requiring custom tooling or local services unsupported. "Hard" vulnerability exploitation cannot be validated; local or external attack tools cannot be executed within the agent's environment.
Underlying language model and its updates are not exposed. Behaviour may change over time; results may not be reproducible and cannot be tuned for determinism.

paragraphsAfter: Table 2 summarises limitations observed in the preview that are not mentioned in the documentation reviewed.

subsections.title: Coverage Visualization
paragraphs: Figure 1 presents an area chart visualizing the OWASP Top 10 coverage percentages across all risk categories, illustrating the significant variation in coverage from complete coverage in injection vulnerabilities to no coverage in software supply chain failures.

chart.caption: Figure 1 - OWASP Top 10 (2025) Coverage by AWS Security Agent
labels: A08: Software or Data Integrity Failures
A09: Security Logging and Alerting Failures

table.caption: Table 3a - A01: Broken Access Control Coverage by AWS Security Agent*
table.note: * The evaluation was conducted against a sample simplified applications with known vulnerabilities. As a result, additional weaknesses or architectural limitations commonly observed in real-world, large-scale applications may not be represented. Analysis of such scenarios is outside the scope of this research.
rows: CWE-1275: Sensitive Cookie with Improper SameSite Attribute

Description: AWS Security Agent may detect cookie security issues through network scanning and TLS/SSL validation, but specific SameSite attribute testing may not be explicitly performed. Evidence: The pubbank-tls pentest run includes "Network scanner (2)" action group that uses testssl.sh (version 3.2.2) for TLS/SSL configuration validation which may include cookie header checks. The service performs network scanning that could identify cookie security misconfigurations. However, explicit SameSite attribute validation may require specific test cases that are not consistently applied across all scenarios. Limitations: Comprehensive SameSite attribute testing requires specific validation of cookie attributes which may not be explicitly tested in all penetration test runs.
CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor

Description: AWS Security Agent detects exposure of sensitive information through information disclosure testing and findings. Evidence: The pubbank-tls pentest run includes "Information disclosure (1)" action group and finding "User Enumeration via Transfer Recipient Validation" (Medium, High Confidence) that demonstrates detection of sensitive information exposure. Finding "Unhandled SQL Execution Errors Expose Server-Side Exceptions via HTTP 500 Responses" (Medium) identifies exposure of sensitive system information through error messages. The service tests for various information disclosure vectors including error messages, directory listings, and user enumeration. Limitations:
CWE-201: Insertion of Sensitive Information Into Sent Data

Description: AWS Security Agent may detect insertion of sensitive information through code scanning and information disclosure testing, but explicit validation of sensitive data in sent messages may not be consistently performed. Evidence: The pubbank-tls pentest run includes "Code scanner (2)" and "Information disclosure (1)" action groups that could identify sensitive information insertion issues. The service performs static analysis and runtime testing that could detect sensitive data being included in sent messages. However, dedicated testing for sensitive information insertion in HTTP responses or API responses may not be explicitly performed in all scenarios. Limitations: Comprehensive testing for sensitive information insertion requires specific validation of all data transmission points which may not be explicitly tested in all penetration test runs.
CWE-219: Storage of File with Sensitive Data Under Web Root

Description: AWS Security Agent may detect files with sensitive data under web root through path traversal and information disclosure testing, but explicit validation of file storage locations may not be consistently performed. Evidence: The pubbank-tls pentest run includes "Path traversal (2)" and "Information disclosure (1)" action groups that could identify sensitive files stored in web-accessible directories. The service performs testing to identify files that can be accessed through path manipulation. However, dedicated testing for sensitive file storage locations may not be explicitly performed in all scenarios. Limitations: Comprehensive testing for sensitive file storage requires specific validation of file system structure and web root configuration which may not be explicitly tested in all penetration test runs.
CWE-22: Improper Limitation of a Pathname to a Restricted Directory ('Path Traversal')

Description: AWS Security Agent tests for path traversal vulnerabilities through dedicated action groups that validate directory traversal attacks. Evidence: The pubbank-tls pentest run (job ID pj-81b57da1-3d51-4870-a3ba-4772f16b1f68) includes a "Path traversal (2)" action group with 2 validator tasks that test for improper pathname limitations. The service performs authenticated runtime testing to identify path traversal vulnerabilities where user-controlled input is used to access files outside restricted directories. Action groups systematically test various path traversal payloads including directory traversal sequences. Limitations:

Description: AWS Security Agent detects relative path traversal vulnerabilities through path traversal testing action groups. Evidence: The pubbank-tls pentest run includes "Path traversal (2)" action group that tests for relative path traversal attacks using sequences like ../ and ..\. The service validates that applications properly restrict relative path access to prevent directory traversal. Testing covers relative path manipulation attempts that could allow unauthorized file access. Limitations:

Description: AWS Security Agent may detect incorrect default permissions through privilege escalation and access control testing, but explicit validation of file system or resource permissions may not be consistently performed. Evidence: The pubbank-tls pentest run includes "Privilege escalation (3)" action group that tests for access control issues which could identify incorrect default permissions. The service performs runtime testing to verify that permissions are correctly enforced. However, dedicated testing for file system or resource-level default permissions may not be explicitly performed in all scenarios. Limitations: Comprehensive testing for default permissions requires specific validation of file system permissions and resource access controls which may not be explicitly tested in all penetration test runs.

Description: AWS Security Agent does not explicitly test for improper preservation of permissions during file operations or resource transfers. Evidence: The service focuses on runtime access control testing and does not include specific validation of permission preservation during file operations. Testing for improper preservation of permissions requires analysis of file system operations and permission inheritance which is outside the scope of web application penetration testing. The service does not perform file system-level permission analysis that would be required to detect this vulnerability. Limitations: Testing for improper preservation of permissions requires file system-level analysis and permission tracking which is not performed by AWS Security Agent.

Description: AWS Security Agent does not explicitly test for improper ownership management of files or resources. Evidence: The service focuses on runtime access control testing and does not include specific validation of file or resource ownership. Testing for improper ownership management requires analysis of file system ownership and access control lists which is outside the scope of web application penetration testing. The service does not perform file system-level ownership analysis that would be required to detect this vulnerability. Limitations: Testing for improper ownership management requires file system-level analysis and ownership tracking which is not performed by AWS Security Agent.

Description: AWS Security Agent may detect unverified ownership through IDOR testing, but explicit validation of ownership verification may not be consistently performed. Evidence: The pubbank-tls pentest run includes "Insecure direct object reference (3)" action group that tests for scenarios where user-controlled identifiers can access resources without ownership verification. The service performs testing to identify cases where ownership is not properly verified before granting access. However, dedicated testing for ownership verification may not be explicitly performed in all scenarios. Limitations: Comprehensive testing for unverified ownership requires specific validation of ownership checks for all resource access operations which may not be explicitly tested in all penetration test runs.

Description: AWS Security Agent detects improper access control through privilege escalation testing and findings that identify access control violations. Evidence: The pubbank-tls pentest run includes "Privilege escalation (3)" action group with 3 validator tasks that test for improper access control. Finding "Remote Code Execution via OS Command Injection in /rce Endpoint" (Critical, Risk Score 9.9) explicitly identifies that "any authenticated user—not just [REDACTED]istrators—can exploit this vulnerability," demonstrating detection of improper access control. The service verifies that authorization decisions are consistently enforced at runtime and that unauthorized requests are reliably rejected. Limitations:

Description: AWS Security Agent identifies improper authorization through privilege escalation testing and authentication bypass findings. Evidence: The pubbank-tls pentest run includes "Privilege escalation (3)" action group that tests for improper authorization where users gain privileges beyond those expected. Finding "SQL Injection in Admin Authentication - Complete Authentication Bypass" (Critical, Risk Score 9.8) demonstrates detection of improper authorization through authentication bypass leading to unauthorized admin access. The service performs authenticated runtime testing to verify that authorization checks are properly implemented and enforced. Limitations:

Description: AWS Security Agent may detect CSRF vulnerabilities through authenticated runtime testing, but explicit CSRF token validation testing may not be consistently performed. Evidence: The service performs authenticated runtime testing that includes session manipulation tests which could identify CSRF vulnerabilities. The pubbank-tls pentest run includes privilege escalation and IDOR testing that verifies authorization enforcement, which could indirectly identify CSRF issues. However, dedicated CSRF action groups or explicit CSRF token validation testing were not observed in the pentest runs analyzed. Limitations: Comprehensive CSRF testing requires specific validation of anti-CSRF tokens and cross-origin request handling which may not be explicitly tested in all scenarios.
CWE-359: Exposure of Private Personal Information to an Unauthorized Actor

Description: AWS Security Agent identifies exposure of private personal information through user enumeration and information disclosure findings. Evidence: The pubbank-tls pentest run includes finding "User Enumeration via Transfer Recipient Validation" (Medium, High Confidence) that demonstrates detection of private personal information exposure through user enumeration. The service tests for scenarios where private personal information can be accessed by unauthorized actors through IDOR vulnerabilities or information disclosure. Testing covers user enumeration, data leakage, and unauthorized access to personal information. Limitations:

Description: AWS Security Agent tests for absolute path traversal vulnerabilities through path traversal action groups. Evidence: The pubbank-tls pentest run includes "Path traversal (2)" action group that validates absolute path traversal attempts using full system paths. The service tests for vulnerabilities where absolute paths can be used to bypass directory restrictions and access files outside intended directories. Testing covers absolute path manipulation that could enable unauthorized file system access. Limitations:

Description: AWS Security Agent does not explicitly test for insecure temporary file creation or usage. Evidence: The service focuses on runtime access control and injection testing and does not include specific validation of temporary file handling. Testing for insecure temporary files requires analysis of file system operations and temporary file creation patterns which is outside the scope of web application penetration testing. The service does not perform file system-level analysis that would be required to detect this vulnerability. Limitations: Testing for insecure temporary files requires file system-level analysis and temporary file tracking which is not performed by AWS Security Agent.
CWE-379: Creation of Temporary File in Directory with Insecure Permissions

Description: AWS Security Agent does not explicitly test for temporary file creation in directories with insecure permissions. Evidence: The service focuses on runtime access control testing and does not include specific validation of temporary file directory permissions. Testing for insecure temporary file directory permissions requires analysis of file system permissions and directory access controls which is outside the scope of web application penetration testing. The service does not perform file system-level permission analysis that would be required to detect this vulnerability. Limitations: Testing for insecure temporary file directory permissions requires file system-level analysis and permission tracking which is not performed by AWS Security Agent.
CWE-402: Transmission of Private Resources into a New Sphere ('Resource Leak')

Description: AWS Security Agent may detect resource leaks through IDOR and information disclosure testing, but explicit validation of resource transmission to unauthorized spheres may not be consistently performed. Evidence: The pubbank-tls pentest run includes "Insecure direct object reference (3)" and "Information disclosure (1)" action groups that could identify resource leaks where private resources are transmitted to unauthorized actors. The service performs testing to identify scenarios where resources are exposed to wrong spheres. However, dedicated testing for resource transmission patterns may not be explicitly performed in all scenarios. Limitations: Comprehensive testing for resource leaks requires specific validation of all resource transmission points and access control enforcement which may not be explicitly tested in all penetration test runs.
CWE-424: Improper Protection of Alternate Path

Description: AWS Security Agent tests for improper protection of alternate paths through privilege escalation and forced browsing testing. Evidence: The pubbank-tls pentest run includes "Privilege escalation (3)" action group that tests for alternate path access where users can bypass primary authentication or authorization controls. The service performs authenticated runtime testing to verify that alternate paths are properly protected and that unauthorized access through alternate routes is prevented. Testing includes attempts to access functionality through alternate endpoints or paths that may have weaker security controls. Limitations:

Description: AWS Security Agent tests for forced browsing vulnerabilities through authenticated runtime testing and privilege escalation action groups. Evidence: The pubbank-tls pentest run includes "Privilege escalation (3)" and "Insecure direct object reference (3)" action groups that test for forced browsing by attempting to access authenticated pages as unauthenticated users and privileged pages as standard users. The service verifies that unauthenticated requests to authenticated pages and unauthorized requests to privileged pages are reliably rejected. Testing includes attempts to access protected resources through direct URL manipulation and guessing. Limitations:
CWE-441: Unintended Proxy or Intermediary ('Confused Deputy')

Description: AWS Security Agent may detect confused deputy vulnerabilities through SSRF testing, but explicit confused deputy validation may not be consistently performed. Evidence: The pubbank-tls pentest run includes "Server side request forgery (4)" action group that tests for SSRF vulnerabilities which could identify confused deputy issues where the application acts as an unintended proxy. The service performs testing to identify scenarios where user-controlled input can be used to make requests to internal or external resources. However, dedicated confused deputy action groups or explicit proxy validation testing were not observed in the pentest runs analyzed. Limitations: Comprehensive confused deputy testing requires specific validation of proxy behavior and resource access patterns which may not be explicitly tested in all scenarios.
CWE-497: Exposure of Sensitive System Information to an Unauthorized Control Sphere

Description: AWS Security Agent detects exposure of sensitive system information through information disclosure testing and error handling analysis. Evidence: The pubbank-tls pentest run includes "Information disclosure (1)" action group and finding "Unhandled SQL Execution Errors Expose Server-Side Exceptions via HTTP 500 Responses" (Medium) that identifies exposure of sensitive system information through error messages. The service tests for various information disclosure vectors including error messages, stack traces, and system information leakage. Testing covers scenarios where sensitive system information can be accessed by unauthorized actors through error handling or information disclosure vulnerabilities. Limitations:
CWE-538: Insertion of Sensitive Information into Externally-Accessible File or Directory

Description: AWS Security Agent may detect insertion of sensitive information through code scanning and information disclosure testing, but explicit validation of sensitive data in externally-accessible files may not be consistently performed. Evidence: The pubbank-tls pentest run includes "Code scanner (2)" and "Information disclosure (1)" action groups that could identify sensitive information in externally-accessible files. The service performs static analysis and path traversal testing that could detect sensitive data in accessible files. However, dedicated testing for sensitive information insertion in externally-accessible files may not be explicitly performed in all scenarios. Limitations: Comprehensive testing for sensitive information insertion requires specific validation of all externally-accessible files and directories which may not be explicitly tested in all penetration test runs.
CWE-540: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Source Code

Description: AWS Security Agent detects inclusion of sensitive information in source code through code scanning and static analysis. Evidence: The pubbank-tls pentest run includes "Code scanner (2)" action group that performs static analysis to identify sensitive information in source code. Finding "Plaintext Admin Password Storage - Critical Credential Protection Failure" (Critical) demonstrates detection of sensitive information (passwords) stored in source code. The service performs code analysis to identify hardcoded credentials, API keys, and other sensitive information in source code. Limitations:
CWE-548: Exposure of Information Through Directory Listing

Description: AWS Security Agent may detect directory listing vulnerabilities through information disclosure and forced browsing testing, but explicit directory listing validation may not be consistently performed. Evidence: The pubbank-tls pentest run includes "Information disclosure (1)" action group and forced browsing testing through privilege escalation action groups that could identify directory listing issues. The service performs testing to identify scenarios where directory listings expose sensitive information. However, dedicated directory listing action groups or explicit directory enumeration testing were not observed in the pentest runs analyzed. Limitations: Comprehensive directory listing testing requires specific validation of directory enumeration and listing behavior which may not be explicitly tested in all scenarios.
CWE-552: Files or Directories Accessible to External Parties

Description: AWS Security Agent tests for externally accessible files and directories through path traversal and forced browsing testing. Evidence: The pubbank-tls pentest run includes "Path traversal (2)" action group that tests for vulnerabilities where files or directories can be accessed through path manipulation. The service performs authenticated runtime testing to verify that files and directories are properly restricted and that unauthorized access to external resources is prevented. Testing includes attempts to access files and directories that should be restricted through path traversal and forced browsing techniques. Limitations:
CWE-566: Authorization Bypass Through User-Controlled SQL Primary Key

Description: AWS Security Agent detects authorization bypass through user-controlled SQL primary keys via IDOR and SQL injection testing. Evidence: The pubbank-tls pentest run includes "Insecure direct object reference (3)" action group that tests for IDOR vulnerabilities where user-controlled identifiers can bypass authorization. The service also includes "Sql injection (4)" action group with 4 validator tasks that could identify SQL-based authorization bypass. Finding "SQL Injection in Admin Authentication - Complete Authentication Bypass" demonstrates detection of authorization bypass through user-controlled input. Testing covers scenarios where SQL primary keys or identifiers can be manipulated to access unauthorized resources. Limitations:
CWE-59: Improper Link Resolution Before File Access ('Link Following')

Description: AWS Security Agent may detect link following vulnerabilities through path traversal testing, but explicit validation of link resolution may not be consistently performed. Evidence: The pubbank-tls pentest run includes "Path traversal (2)" action group that tests for path manipulation which could identify link following issues. The service performs testing to identify scenarios where links can be used to access unauthorized files. However, dedicated testing for link resolution and following may not be explicitly performed in all scenarios. Limitations: Comprehensive testing for link following requires specific validation of symbolic link and hard link handling which may not be explicitly tested in all penetration test runs.
CWE-601: URL Redirection to Untrusted Site ('Open Redirect')

Description: AWS Security Agent may detect open redirect vulnerabilities through business logic and authentication testing, but explicit open redirect validation may not be consistently performed. Evidence: The pubbank-tls pentest run includes "Business logic vulnerabilities (12)" action group that tests for various business logic flaws which could include open redirect issues. The service performs authenticated runtime testing that could identify redirect vulnerabilities. However, dedicated open redirect action groups or explicit redirect validation testing were not observed in the pentest runs analyzed. Limitations: Comprehensive open redirect testing requires specific validation of redirect parameters and untrusted URL handling which may not be explicitly tested in all scenarios.

Description: AWS Security Agent may detect symlink following vulnerabilities through path traversal testing, but explicit validation of symlink resolution may not be consistently performed. Evidence: The pubbank-tls pentest run includes "Path traversal (2)" action group that tests for path manipulation which could identify symlink following issues. The service performs testing to identify scenarios where symbolic links can be used to access unauthorized files. However, dedicated testing for symlink resolution and following may not be explicitly performed in all scenarios. Limitations: Comprehensive testing for symlink following requires specific validation of symbolic link handling and resolution which may not be explicitly tested in all penetration test runs.
CWE-615: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Source Code Comments

Description: AWS Security Agent may detect sensitive information in source code comments through code scanning, but explicit validation of comment content may not be consistently performed. Evidence: The pubbank-tls pentest run includes "Code scanner (2)" action group that performs static analysis which could identify sensitive information in comments. The service performs code analysis that may detect sensitive data in comments. However, dedicated testing for sensitive information in code comments may not be explicitly performed in all scenarios. Limitations: Comprehensive testing for sensitive information in comments requires specific validation of comment content which may not be explicitly tested in all code scanning operations.
CWE-639: Authorization Bypass Through User-Controlled Key

Description: AWS Security Agent detects authorization bypass through user-controlled keys via insecure direct object reference testing. Evidence: The pubbank-tls pentest run includes "Insecure direct object reference (3)" action group with 3 validator tasks that test for IDOR vulnerabilities where user identifiers can be manipulated. Finding "User Enumeration via Transfer Recipient Validation" (Medium, High Confidence) demonstrates detection of vulnerabilities where user-controlled keys can be used to access other users' information. The service tests for scenarios where user-supplied identifiers can be modified to bypass authorization checks and access unauthorized resources. Limitations:

Description: AWS Security Agent does not explicitly test for Windows hard link vulnerabilities. Evidence: The service focuses on web application penetration testing and does not include specific validation of Windows-specific file system features like hard links. Testing for Windows hard link vulnerabilities requires analysis of Windows file system operations which is outside the scope of web application penetration testing. The service does not perform Windows-specific file system analysis that would be required to detect this vulnerability. Limitations: Testing for Windows hard link vulnerabilities requires Windows-specific file system analysis which is not performed by AWS Security Agent.
CWE-668: Exposure of Resource to Wrong Sphere

Description: AWS Security Agent detects exposure of resources to wrong spheres through IDOR and privilege escalation testing. Evidence: The pubbank-tls pentest run includes "Insecure direct object reference (3)" and "Privilege escalation (3)" action groups that test for scenarios where resources are exposed to unauthorized actors. Finding "User Enumeration via Transfer Recipient Validation" demonstrates detection of resources exposed to wrong spheres through IDOR vulnerabilities. The service verifies that resources are properly isolated and that access controls prevent exposure to unauthorized spheres. Limitations:
CWE-732: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource

Description: AWS Security Agent identifies incorrect permission assignment through privilege escalation testing and findings that detect unauthorized access to critical resources. Evidence: The pubbank-tls pentest run includes "Privilege escalation (3)" action group that tests for incorrect permission assignment where users gain access to critical resources beyond their intended permissions. Finding "Remote Code Execution via OS Command Injection in /rce Endpoint" identifies that critical admin functionality is accessible to any authenticated user, demonstrating incorrect permission assignment. The service verifies that permissions are correctly assigned and that critical resources are properly protected. Limitations:
CWE-749: Exposed Dangerous Method or Function

Description: AWS Security Agent detects exposed dangerous methods or functions through code scanning and runtime testing. Evidence: The pubbank-tls pentest run includes "Code scanner (2)" action group that performs static analysis to identify exposed dangerous methods. Finding "Remote Code Execution via OS Command Injection in /rce Endpoint" identifies that a dangerous command execution function is exposed to authenticated users without proper restrictions. The service performs code analysis and runtime testing to identify exposed dangerous methods that should be restricted or require additional security controls. Limitations:

Description: AWS Security Agent identifies missing authorization through privilege escalation testing and findings that detect unauthorized access to protected functionality. Evidence: The pubbank-tls pentest run includes "Privilege escalation (3)" action group that tests for missing authorization on protected endpoints. Finding "Remote Code Execution via OS Command Injection in /rce Endpoint" identifies that admin functionality is accessible to any authenticated user without proper authorization checks. The service performs authenticated runtime testing to verify that authorization is consistently enforced and that missing authorization controls are detected. Limitations:

Description: AWS Security Agent detects incorrect authorization through privilege escalation and authentication bypass findings. Evidence: The pubbank-tls pentest run includes "Privilege escalation (3)" action group that tests for incorrect authorization where users gain privileges beyond those expected. Finding "SQL Injection in Admin Authentication - Complete Authentication Bypass" demonstrates detection of incorrect authorization through authentication bypass. The service verifies that authorization decisions are correctly implemented and that incorrect authorization logic is identified through runtime testing. Limitations:

Description: AWS Security Agent tests for SSRF vulnerabilities through dedicated action groups that validate server-side request forgery attacks. Evidence: The pubbank-tls pentest run includes "Server side request forgery (4)" action group with 4 validator tasks that test for SSRF vulnerabilities. The service performs testing to identify scenarios where user-controlled input can be used to make requests to internal or external resources. Testing covers SSRF attack vectors that could allow access to internal systems or cloud metadata services. Limitations:
CWE-922: Insecure Storage of Sensitive Information

Description: AWS Security Agent detects insecure storage of sensitive information through code scanning and findings that identify credential protection failures. Evidence: The pubbank-tls pentest run includes "Code scanner (2)" action group that performs static analysis to identify insecure storage of sensitive information. Finding "Plaintext Admin Password Storage - Critical Credential Protection Failure" (Critical) demonstrates detection of insecure storage where passwords are stored in plaintext. The service performs code analysis and runtime testing to identify insecure storage patterns including plaintext credentials, unencrypted sensitive data, and weak storage mechanisms. Limitations:

sections.title: Conclusion and Recommendations
paragraphs: AWS Security Agent represents a shift toward continuous, embedded application security. It automates design and code reviews, runs realistic multi-step penetration tests and centralizes findings, enabling teams to identify issues earlier and reduce manual effort. The service's context-aware approach, custom security requirements and multi-step attack simulations are valuable features.

However, the preview version has notable limitations: it is available only in one region, requires manual configuration through a web interface, supports only private GitHub repositories, lacks scheduling and API automation (scheduled testing is explicitly documented as unavailable [9]), and cannot handle complex exploitation scenarios or non-HTTP protocols. Only GitHub integration is supported; other SCM systems (GitLab, Bitbucket, CodeCommit) are not available [3]. The service provides strong coverage for injection vulnerabilities and access control, moderate coverage for security misconfiguration and insecure design, but has significant gaps in software supply chain security, cryptographic validation beyond TLS checks, logging and alerting, and data integrity failures. To fully secure their applications, organizations should use AWS Security Agent as a complementary control alongside additional tools and processes (e.g., dependency scanning, secrets management, infrastructure‑as‑code security, and runtime monitoring) and maintain human expertise for nuanced assessments.

references.title: What is AWS Security Agent? - AWS Security Agent
references.description: Official AWS Security Agent documentation describing key capabilities (design security review, code security review, penetration testing), benefits (on-demand accessibility, automatic validation of organizational requirements, scalable security expertise, actionable fixes, multi and hybrid cloud support), and how the service operates across the development lifecycle. The documentation states that the agent provides design reviews, code security reviews and multi-step penetration testing within a centralized web interface.

references.title: AWS Security Agent (Preview): AI agent for proactive app security
references.description: AWS What's New announcement from December 2, 2025, announcing the preview of AWS Security Agent, an AI-powered agent that proactively secures applications throughout the development lifecycle. The announcement describes automated security reviews, context-aware penetration testing, and validation from design to deployment.

references.title: Review code security findings in GitHub - AWS Security Agent
references.description: Official AWS Security Agent documentation explaining how code review works in GitHub, including that code review is triggered when a pull request is marked as "Ready for review" and that draft pull requests are not analyzed

references.title: New AWS Security Agent secures applications proactively from design to deployment (preview)
references.description: AWS News Feed post summarising features including automated design, code and penetration tests, context awareness and OWASP Top 10 code checks

references.title: Service Quotas - AWS Security Agent
references.description: Official AWS Security Agent documentation listing service quotas including operations quotas (pentest hours: 80/month, design reviews: 200/month, code reviews: 1,000/month) and configuration quotas (integrations: 20 per account per region, integrated resources per integration: 20, custom security requirements: 20 per account per region, concurrent pentest runs: 5 per account per region)

references.title: Create a penetration test - AWS Security Agent
references.description: Official AWS Security Agent documentation describing how to create penetration tests, including prerequisites, configuration of test scope, target domains (only verified domains can be tested), VPC resources (only required for private applications), authentication credentials, and additional resources

references.title: AWS Debuts Security Agent for Automated Code-Level Protection
references.description: National CIO Review article noting that AWS Security Agent automates penetration testing tailored to application design and code

references.title: AWS targets vulnerable code with security agent
references.description: ComputerWeekly report highlighting that AWS Security Agent continuously scans for security violations, conducts on-demand penetration tests and ties security across the development lifecycle

references.title: Security Considerations for AWS Security Agent and AI assisted penetration testing - AWS Security Agent
references.description: Official AWS Security Agent documentation on security considerations, explicitly stating that AWS Security Agent does not have public APIs or the ability to schedule penetration test runs

references.title: Security best practices for AWS Security Agent - AWS Security Agent
references.description: Official AWS Security Agent documentation on security best practices, including code repository access limitations stating that AWS Security Agent does not provide code security guidance for public repositories

references.title: Connect agent to private VPC resources - AWS Security Agent
references.description: Official AWS Security Agent documentation on connecting the agent to private VPC resources, explicitly stating that VPC CIDR ranges that overlap with the 10.0.0.0/16 range are currently not supported for VPC penetration tests

references.title: Infrastructure security in AWS Security Agent - AWS Security Agent
references.description: Official AWS Security Agent documentation on infrastructure security, stating that AWS Security Agent requires internet access to perform penetration testing on target applications and for control plane operations

references.title: OWASP Top 10:2025
references.description: OWASP Top 10:2025 list of application security risks
